title: 111_hr1285
content: The "Commission on the Foreclosure and Mortgage Lending Crisis Act" establishes a commission in the legislative branch to address the foreclosure and mortgage lending crisis. Congress finds a steady increase in foreclosures and mortgage lending problems impacting the US economy. In 2006, there were 1.3 million foreclosures, increasing to 2.2 million in 2007 and 3.2 million in 2008. The trend is expected to continue with millions more Americans at risk of losing their homes. The purpose of the Act is to establish a commission to analyze the causes of the crisis. The Commission will analyze the causes of the foreclosure and mortgage lending crisis, provide findings to Congress, and recommend legislative changes to prevent similar lending practices. The Commission will analyze the causes of the foreclosure and mortgage lending crisis, provide findings to Congress, and recommend legislative changes to prevent similar lending practices. SEC. 4. COMPOSITION. The Commission, composed of 10 members appointed by various leaders and officials, must be fully appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Two members from subsection (a) will be designated as Co-Chairmen. The Co-Chairmen of the Commission are designated by leaders from the House of Representatives and the Senate. Vacancies in the Commission will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses for Commission-related services. The Commission members are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, in accordance with section 5703 of title 5, United States Code. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 60 days of the Act's enactment and subsequent meetings will be called by a majority of members. A majority of members constitutes a quorum, and the Commission may establish rules for its proceedings. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission's duties include studying the housing mortgage lending markets, assessing the impact of lending practices on the foreclosure rate, recommending changes to the legal framework, reviewing subprime abuses, and assessing the role of States in reducing predatory lending practices. The Commission's duties include studying the housing mortgage lending markets, assessing the impact of mortgage-backed securities, Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, and the Community Reinvestment Act on the mortgage lending crisis. They are required to submit a final report to Congress within 12 months, with a possible 6-month extension if needed. The Commission is granted powers under Section 6. The Commission, under Section 6, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas with majority approval for the attendance of witnesses and production of documents. Subpoenas issued by the Commission can be enforced by the United States district court in case of non-compliance. The Commission can enforce subpoenas through the court, and failure to comply may result in contempt charges or referral to the United States attorney for further action. The Commission has the authority to enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies to carry out its duties under the Act. The Commission can request suggestions, estimates, and statistics from federal agencies. Information must be handled by Commission members and staff according to laws and regulations. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission. Other US departments and agencies can also assist the Commission. The Commission can receive support from the United States for services, funds, facilities, staff, and other needs as authorized by law. They can also utilize postal services and appoint staff without following standard hiring procedures. The Commission can appoint staff without following standard hiring procedures, and the staff director and personnel are considered federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. The Commission can appoint staff without standard hiring procedures. Members of the Commission are exempt from certain rules. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can procure expert services at specified rates. The Commission can accept voluntary and uncompensated services as necessary under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7 states that the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission is required to hold public meetings, release public versions of reports, and conduct public hearings in a manner that protects sensitive information. SEC. 8 discusses the termination of the Commission. SEC. 8 of the Act states that the Commission and its authorities will terminate within 60 days after submitting the final report. The Commission can use this period to conclude its activities, testify before Congress, and disseminate the final report. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for the Act.
